ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Black feminist theory and new ways of viewing black people, blackness as a concept and the structures of power in place that keep Black people subordinated. What was most interesting to me was understanding the origins of modern stereotypes about Black people.
ways to integrate art history and social theory forms of analysis

I learned about the art of many Black artists who I would not know otherwise, and well as developed comfort talking about art in an academic setting. The theory was often really dense at times and went over my head, but I appreciated being exposed to it and see myself coming back to these ideas in my future education, even if they did not make the most sense now. I also really loved our YUAG trips!

Not a art history major but learned how to do a proper visual analysis. Learned how to synthesize theoretical, historical, and visual analysis to defend my thesis. Overall became more confident as a person because of the relevance of the material.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked that we viewed the art in person. It is so much better to view art in person than online. This course was super theory heavy and it seemed that the professor operated on the assumption that everyone knew how to read theory. I did not understand a lot of the texts until it was explained to me and even then I couldnt reproduce the ideas of the text. It was like learning a new language. I think there should have been less texts per week so that students could get a greater understanding of the texts. I found myself reading only half the text in an effort to understand each one at least partially but make sure to get to all of them. Also, we werent really trained on how to analyze art or even discussed it but we then had to write a paper about it. I wouldve appreciated more guidance in that area.
Sometimes, when Professor Ekpo lectured without a visual aid, it was a bit difficult to follow. Her discussion of ideas could move very quickly, and I don't know if everything absorbed.

I loved the subject matter of this course. The connections drawn between visual art and Black feminist theory were enthralling and helped me to learn so much about a subject I previously knew little about.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have a good understanding of theory already, I would recommend the course. It is super cool to see the pieces of art we discuss in person however were not taught how to analyze art. I feel like it was a lot of me figuring out how to do things or asking my writing tutor mostly.

I would recommend this course if you are prepared to struggle with difficult ideas relating to Blackness and gender. I often felt intellectually out-of-depth, but Professor Ekpo is so generous with her time and ideas and is always around to meet for office hours to discuss the course content further. All of the art was great!
Yes. I have recommended this course to all of my friends who have expressed interest in taking anything like it.
I would recommend this course to any student trying to expand their knowledge on the experiences of Black women and inclusive feminist concepts.
